author: shresth
content: Why don't we increase the `MIN_SYNC_COMMITTEE_PARTICIPANTS` to a reasonable number such that this kind of attack requires a larger stake?

author: pietjepuk
content:
If I understand your reasoning correctly, you rely on:
- an entity having a validator in the sync committee
- said entity being able to eclipse a particular light client

By that logic, increasing `MIN_SYNC_COMMITTEE_PARTICIPANTS` would only make the problem worse no?

author: shresth
content: Increasing `MIN_SYNC_COMMITTEE_PARTICIPANTS` would imply you would need more more participants in the sync committee consider an update valid? As per my understanding that should help

author: etan_status
content:
It is up to the use case and the client implementation to determine what risk profile to apply. 
The standard "safe" mechanism is using 2/3 majority, as well as requires a `finality_proof`. 
This is the behaviour you get if you just never call `process_slot_for_light_client_store`. Anything else is heuristics based.

The only time when you can _realistically_ get stuck following that, is:
– no finality for an entire sync committee period
– low sync committee participation (< 2/3) for an entire sync committee period
If your use case cannot fallback to an alternate syncing mechanism to cover such edge case periods, you need a heuristic to avoid getting stuck.
